content: Thank you for responding. Your request came as I was talking to my friend who is a Devry Grad and he removed the problem. His solution was to go to VIEW on the Instructions in the upper left and then to Layout and then to uncheck the MESSAGES which was checked in the lower part of the choices. Viola, what I was complaining about was eliminated, Obviously I cannot send you a copy of what was irritating me as it no longer exists. Yay! Thanks for following up, however. It is much appreciated as I was totally incensed. My Thunderbird site just had an update today and I presume that is why the Messages got checked again. It is no longer.
creator: lois_stevens

content:
In your message page, you should have at least a From column, a Subject column, and a Date column. If you click your mouse just to the right of the word Date, your message order will reverse, and the newest ones will be at the top.

Please come back and explain in more detail if this isn't what you want.

content:
I suppose the second user would have to never open Thunderbird from a menu. Without the instruction in the shortcut to use their profile, I expect it would try to load the first user's (which might not be visible in their login) and hit problems.

Can't help thinking Thunderbird should be slicker at dealing with multi-user operating systems where everyone has their own UI and data folder.
creator: carlwark

content:
This can be done several ways, but here is my simple approach: - install thunderbird with one of the two profiles - copy the other profile to same folder c:\users\<userid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles (although any place would work) - on desktop, copy and paste the thunderbird icon so that there are two on desktop - rightclick on second icon, select 'target' and add to right 

    -profilemgr  "c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles\<profilename>" (or wherever you placed the second profile)

- rename icon as desired.
creator: davidsk

content: Grazie mille, è proprio così. Devo per forza cambiare modo di archiviazione delle email, altrimenti ogni giorno i software di backup copiano 60gb di email!
creator: lpinna6

content:
Non conosco Mail, ma posso ipotizzare che dipenda dal formato in cui sono memorizzati i messaggi email. Da quel che leggo in giro, Mail salva i messaggi in file singoli, questo fa si che i backup incrementali possano essere limitati ai nuovi messaggi. Thunderbird invece usa un formato monolitico chiamato mbox in cui ogni cartella di Thunderbird corrisponde ad un singolo file su disco. La nuova posta vine salvata in coda ai file già esistenti che quindi risulteranno modificati e verranno salvati nuovamente in ogni backup.

Soluzioni? 1) Una possibile soluzione è quella di raccogliere i messaggi più vecchi in singole cartelle. Queste non venendo modificate ogni volta, dovrebbero funzionare bene anche in un backup incrementale. 2) Esiste anche la possibilità di impostare Thunderbird per salvare i messaggi in file singoli come spiegato qui https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/maildir-thunderbird Ma è una funzione sperimentale, incompleta e con numerosi bug non risolti per cui ti sconsiglio di usarla
creator: @next

content: The msgFilterRules.dat file can be copied between accounts on the same or different computers. It's located in the account subfolder of Mail or ImapMail in the profile folder, e.g. ImapMail/imap.gmail.com. Copy the file with TB closed.
creator: sfhowes
